text: Correlation tables can constructed using apa.cor.table() function. constructed table includes descriptive statistics (.e., mean standard deviation) variable confidence interval correlation. apa.cor.table() function creates correlation table confidence intervals based data frame. example creates APA Style correlation table, see Table 1, using attitude dataset built R. title: apaTables
text: Regression tables can constructed using apa.reg.table() function. constructed table includes unstandardized regression coefficient (b CI), standardized regression coefficient (beta CI), semi-partial correlation squared (\(sr^2\) CI), correlation (\(r\)), overall fit model (indexed \(R^2\) CI). album sales dataset Field et al. (2012) used illustrate apa.reg.table() function.

title: apaTables
text: Prior begining ‘open’ apaTables, tidyverse, ez packages using library command per . example, used drink_attitude dataset Field et al. (2012). , dataset built apaTables need loaded using read_csv() read_sav(). dataset (drink_attitude_wide) can inspected glimpse() command (provides information similar SPSS variable view). use “wide” descriptor name dataset remind us data “wide” format one row contains data one person. 20 participants 20 rows. dataset represents ANOVA two repeated measures factors. 3 drinks (wine, beer, water) X 3 imagery (positive, negative, neutral) design. dataset uses 10 columns represent design. first column contains code participant (P1, P2, etc.) Note participant column factor indicated < fctr > descriptor. participant column must factor can, noted previously, created as_factor() command. remaining 9 columns contain atittude ratings single drink/imagery combination cell. naming convention column names critical workflow describe . column name represents level drink variable separated using underscore ( _ ) level imagery variable. example first column called beer_positive representing cell combination beer level drink positive level imagery. value column represents attitude participant cell. order conduct repeated measures ANOVA need convert dataset wide format (row represents person) long format (row represents single observation person). series commands . can inspect final long version dataset glimpse : output reveals new data structure. now four columns row represents single observation participant. , first column factor column representing participant. participant represented nines times column now - participant nine observations (.e., one nine cells). importantly, now single column indicating level drink, single column indicating level imagery, column indicating attitude rating. can see first rows familiar format : Prior conducting analysis set contrasts per Field et al. (2012). use ezANOVA command ez package conduct repeated measures ANOVA. sure include commands including options command ensures output sufficent number digits (.e., numbers decimal) apaTables. Now make table based output: 2-way Repeated Measures ANOVA MSWord Use apa.knit.table..pdf() function create latex table papaja Quarto documents:
code: library(apaTables) library(tidyverse) library(ez) glimpse(drink_attitude_wide) drink_attitude_long <- tidyr::pivot_longer(drink_attitude_wide,                               cols = beer_positive:water_neutral,                               names_to = c("drink", "imagery"),                               names_sep = "_",                               values_to = "attitude")   drink_attitude_long$drink <- as_factor(drink_attitude_long$drink) drink_attitude_long$imagery <- as_factor(drink_attitude_long$imagery) glimpse(drink_attitude_long) head(drink_attitude_long) alcohol_vs_water <- c(1, 1, -2) beer_vs_wine <- c(-1, 1, 0) negative_vs_other <- c(1, -2, 1) positive_vs_neutral <- c(-1, 0, 1) contrasts(drink_attitude_long$drink) <- cbind(alcohol_vs_water, beer_vs_wine) contrasts(drink_attitude_long$imagery) <- cbind(negative_vs_other, positive_vs_neutral) options(digits = 10)  drink_attitude_results <- ezANOVA(data = drink_attitude_long,                                   dv = .(attitude),                                   wid = .(participant),                                   within = .(drink, imagery),                                   type = 3,                                   detailed = TRUE) table11 <- apa.ezANOVA.table(drink_attitude_results,                              table.number = 11)  apa.save(filename = "table11.doc",          table11) apa.knit.table.for.pdf(table11)

title: apaTables
text: Prior begining ‘open’ apaTables, tidyverse, ez packages using library command per . example, used drink_attitude dataset Field et al. (2012). , dataset built apaTables. dataset (dating_wide) can inspected glimpse() command (provides information similar SPSS variable view). use “wide” descriptor name dataset remind us data “wide” format one row contains data one person. 20 participants 20 rows. dataset represents ANOVA one independent groups factor two repeated measures factors. 2 gender (male, female) 3 looks (attrative, average, ugly) X 3 personality (high, , none) design. dataset uses 11 columns represent design. first column contains code participant (P1, P2, etc.) Note participant column factor indicated “< fctr >” descriptor. second column used indicate gender participant. participant gender columns factors. remaining 9 columns contain atittude ratings single looks/personality combination cell. naming convention column names critical workflow describe . column name represents level looks variable separated using underscore ( _ ) level personality variable. example first column called attractive_high representing cell combination attractive level looks high level personality. value column represents date rating participant cell. order conduct mixed /within ANOVA need convert dataset wide format (row represents person) long format (row represents single observation person) – taking account independent groups factors (gender). series commands . can inspect final long version dataset glimpse : output reveals new data structure. now five columns row represents single observation participant. , first column factor column representing participant. participant represented nines times column now - participant nine observations (.e., one nine cells). second column contains gender factor. third column indicates level looks, fourth column indicates level personality. fith column indicates date_rating. can see first rows familiar format : Prior conducting analysis set contrasts per Field et al. (2012). use ezANOVA command ez package conduct repeated measures ANOVA. sure include commands including options command ensures output sufficent number digits (.e., numbers decimal) apaTables. Now make table based output: 3-way Mixed Measures ANOVA MSWord Use apa.knit.table..pdf() function create latex table papaja Quarto documents:
code: library(apaTables) library(tidyverse) library(ez) glimpse(dating_wide) dating_long <- tidyr::pivot_longer(dating_wide,                                    cols = attractive_high:ugly_none,                                    names_to = c("looks", "personality"),                                    names_sep = "_",                                    values_to = "date_rating")   dating_long$looks <- as_factor(dating_long$looks) dating_long$personality <- as_factor(dating_long$personality) glimpse(dating_long) head(dating_long) some_vs_none <- c(1, 1, -2) hi_vs_av <- c(1, -1, 0) attractive_vs_ugly <- c(1, 1, -2) attractive_vs_average <- c(1, -1, 0) contrasts(dating_long$personality) <- cbind(some_vs_none, hi_vs_av) contrasts(dating_long$looks) <- cbind(attractive_vs_ugly, attractive_vs_average) options(digits = 10) dating_results <-ezANOVA(data = dating_long,                           dv = .(date_rating),                          wid = .(participant),                          between = .(gender),                          within = .(looks, personality),                          type = 3,                          detailed = TRUE) table12 <- apa.ezANOVA.table(dating_results,                                    filename = "Table12_APA.doc",                                    table.number = 12)  apa.save(filename = "table12.doc",          table12) apa.knit.table.for.pdf(table12)

code: # Example 1: 1-way from Field et al. (2012) Discovery Statistics Using R  table1 <- apa.1way.table(iv = dose, dv = libido,                data = viagra, table.number = 1)  apa.save(filename = "table1.doc", table1)  # Create a table for your PDF # Include the line below in your rmarkdown or Quarto document apa.knit.table.for.pdf(table1) #> \renewcommand{\arraystretch}{1}\begin{table} #>  #> \caption{Descriptive Statistics For Libido For Each Level Of Dose. } #> \fontsize{10}{12}\selectfont #> \begin{threeparttable} #> \begin{tabular}[t]{lrr} #> \toprule #> dose & $M$ & $SD$\\ #> \midrule #> Placebo & 2.20 & 1.30\\ #> Low Dose & 3.20 & 1.30\\ #> High Dose & 5.00 & 1.58\\ #> \bottomrule #> \end{tabular} #> \begin{tablenotes} #> \item \textit{Note}. \textit{M} = mean. \textit{SD} = standard deviation.  #> \end{tablenotes} #> \end{threeparttable} #> \end{table} #> \renewcommand{\arraystretch}{1} #>    # delete demo file if (file.exists("table1.doc")) {      file.remove("table1.doc") } #> [1] TRUE

code: if  (requireNamespace("ez", quietly = TRUE)){ if  (requireNamespace("apaTables", quietly = TRUE)){ if  (requireNamespace("tidyr", quietly = TRUE)){   # # ** Example 1: Between Participant Predictors #  goggles <- apaTables::goggles  # Use ezANOVA # Be sure use the options command, as below, to ensure sufficient digits  options(digits = 10) goggles_results <- ez::ezANOVA(data = goggles,                           dv = attractiveness,                           between = .(gender, alcohol),                           participant ,                           detailed = TRUE)   # Make APA table - save after all 3 examples goggles_table <- apa.ezANOVA.table(goggles_results)  # Create a table for your PDF # Include the lines below in your rmarkdown or Quarto document apa.knit.table.for.pdf(goggles_table)   # # ** Example 2: Within Participant Predictors #  drink_attitude_wide <- apaTables::drink_attitude_wide  # Convert data from wide format to long format where one row represents one OBSERVATION. # Wide format column names MUST represent levels of each variable separated by an underscore. # See vignette for further details.  drink_attitude_long <- tidyr::pivot_longer(drink_attitude_wide,                               cols = beer_positive:water_neutral,                              names_to = c("drink", "imagery"),                              names_sep = "_",                               values_to = "attitude")   drink_attitude_long$drink <- as.factor(drink_attitude_long$drink) drink_attitude_long$imagery <- as.factor(drink_attitude_long$imagery)   # Set contrasts to match Field et al. (2012) textbook output  alcohol_vs_water <- c(1, 1, -2) beer_vs_wine <- c(-1, 1, 0) negative_vs_other <- c(1, -2, 1) positive_vs_neutral <- c(-1, 0, 1) contrasts(drink_attitude_long$drink) <- cbind(alcohol_vs_water, beer_vs_wine) contrasts(drink_attitude_long$imagery) <- cbind(negative_vs_other, positive_vs_neutral)   # Use ezANOVA # Be sure use the options command, as below, to ensure sufficient digits  options(digits = 10) drink_attitude_results <- ez::ezANOVA(data = drink_attitude_long,                    dv = .(attitude), wid = .(participant),                    within = .(drink, imagery),                    type = 3, detailed = TRUE)   # Make APA table - save after all 3 examples drink_table <- apa.ezANOVA.table(drink_attitude_results)  # Create a table for your PDF # Include the lines below in your rmarkdown or Quarto document apa.knit.table.for.pdf(drink_table)   # # ** Example 3: Between and Within Participant Predictors #  dating_wide <- apaTables::dating_wide  # Convert data from wide format to long format where one row represents one OBSERVATION. # Wide format column names MUST represent levels of each variable separated by an underscore. # See vignette for further details.   dating_long <- tidyr::pivot_longer(dating_wide,                               cols = attractive_high:ugly_none,                              names_to = c("looks", "personality"),                              names_sep = "_",                               values_to = "date_rating") #' dating_long$looks <- as.factor(dating_long$looks) dating_long$personality <- as.factor(dating_long$personality)   # Set contrasts to match Field et al. (2012) textbook output  some_vs_none <- c(1, 1, -2) hi_vs_av <- c(1, -1, 0) attractive_vs_ugly <- c(1, 1, -2) attractive_vs_average <- c(1, -1, 0) contrasts(dating_long$personality) <- cbind(some_vs_none, hi_vs_av) contrasts(dating_long$looks) <- cbind(attractive_vs_ugly, attractive_vs_average)   # Use ezANOVA  options(digits = 10) dating_results <-ez::ezANOVA(data = dating_long, dv = .(date_rating),                          wid = .(participant),                          between = .(gender),                          within = .(looks, personality),                          type = 3, detailed = TRUE)   # Make APA table - save after all 3 examples dating_table <- apa.ezANOVA.table(dating_results)  # Create a table for your PDF # Include the lines below in your rmarkdown or Quarto document apa.knit.table.for.pdf(dating_table)   # # Saving all three tables # apa.save("tables_ezANOVA.doc",                 goggles_table,                  drink_table,                 dating_table)  # delete demo file if (file.exists("tables_ezANOVA.doc")) {      file.remove("tables_ezANOVA.doc") } }}} #> Coefficient covariances computed by hccm() #> [1] TRUE

text: ... Regression (.e., lm) result objects. Typically, one block regression. filename (optional) Output filename document filename (must end .rtf .doc ) table.number Integer use table number output line prop.var.conf.level Level confidence (.90 .95, default .95) interval around sr2, R2, Delta R2. Use .90 confidence level helps create consistency CI overlapping zero conclusions based p-value block (block difference).

title: Creates a regresion table in APA style — apa.reg.table
text: sr2 delta R2 confidence intervals calculated via: Alf Jr, E. F., & Graf, R. G. (1999). Asymptotic confidence limits difference two squared multiple correlations: simplified approach. Psychological Methods, 4(1), 70. Note Algina, Keselman, & Penfield (2008) found approach can circumstances lead inaccurate CIs proportion variance values. might consider using Algina, Keselman, & Penfield (2008) approach via apa.reg.boot.table function

N = 200. b = unstandardized regression weight. beta = standardized regression weight. Unique R2 = semipartial correlation squared. r = zero-order correlation. CI = confidence interval.   #> * indicates p < .05. ** indicates p < .01. #>   #>  table1 <- apa.reg.table(blk1,table.number = 1)  # Two block example, more than two blocks can be used blk1 <- lm(sales ~ adverts, data=album) blk2 <- lm(sales ~ adverts + airplay + attract, data=album) table2 <- apa.reg.table(blk1, blk2, table.number = 2)  # Interaction product-term test with blocks blk1 <- lm(sales ~ adverts + airplay, data=album) blk2 <- lm(sales ~ adverts + airplay + I(adverts * airplay), data=album) table3 <- apa.reg.table(blk1, blk2, table.number = 3)  # Interaction product-term test with blocks and additional product terms blk1<-lm(sales ~ adverts + airplay, data=album) blk2<-lm(sales ~ adverts + airplay + I(adverts*adverts) + I(airplay*airplay), data=album) blk3<-lm(sales~adverts+airplay+I(adverts*adverts)+I(airplay*airplay)+I(adverts*airplay),data=album) table4 <- apa.reg.table(blk1,blk2,blk3, table.number = 4)  #Interaction product-term test with single regression (i.e., semi-partial correlation focus) blk1 <- lm(sales ~ adverts + airplay + I(adverts * airplay), data=album) table5 <- apa.reg.table(blk1, table.number = 5)  # code: library(apaTables)  table1 <- apa.1way.table(iv = dose, dv = libido,                data = viagra, table.number = 1)  table2 <- apa.2way.table(iv1 = gender, iv2 = alcohol,                          dv = attractiveness,                          data = goggles, table.number = 1)  apa.save(filename = "my.tables.doc", table1, table2)  # delete demo file if (file.exists("my.tables.doc")) {      file.remove("my.tables.doc") } #> [1] TRUE

what: Create American Psychological Association (APA) Style Tables — apaTables
title: Create American Psychological Association (APA) Style Tables — apaTables
text: common task faced researchers creation APA style (.e., American Psychological Association style) tables statistical output. R large number function calls often needed obtain desired information single APA style table. well, process manually creating APA style tables word processor prone transcription errors. package creates Word files (.doc files) latex code containing APA style tables several types analyses. Using package minimizes transcription errors reduces number commands needed user. Examples provided documentation http://www.StatsCanBeFun.com.

title: Create American Psychological Association (APA) Style Tables — apaTables
text: Bugs feature requests can reported : https://github.com/dstanley4/apaTables/issues Tutorial : https://dstanley4.github.io/apaTables/articles/apaTables.html Currently, following tables can created: Correlation tables - Correlation tables (confidence intervals descriptive statistics) created data frames using apa.cor.table. Single "block" regression tables - Single "block" regression tables created regression object using apa.reg.table. Multiple "block" regression tables - Multiple "block" regression tables created regression objects using apa.reg.table. ANOVA tables - ANOVA F-table can created via apa.aov.table regression object (.e. lm output aov output). Cell mean/standard deviation tables 1- 2-way designs created data frames using apa.1way.table apa.2way.table. ezANOVA tables ez package - ANOVA F-table ezANOVA output can created via apa.ezANOVA.table. Standardized mean difference (.e., d-value) tables (confidence intervals descriptive statistics) illustrating possible paired comparisons using single independent variable created data frames using apa.d.table.
